mainPage.title: Nuxt 3 Best Practices
mainPage.content:
Building Production-Ready Nuxt 3 Applications

Nuxt 3 is a powerful Vue.js framework that provides an intuitive way to build performant web applications with server-side rendering, static site generation, and hybrid rendering capabilities.

Why Follow Best Practices?

Following best practices ensures your applications are:

  • Performant: Fast initial load times and smooth interactions
  • Maintainable: Easy to understand and extend over time
  • Scalable: Ready to grow with your business needs
  • SEO-Friendly: Optimized for search engine visibility

Core Principles

The key principles covered in this wiki include proper project structure, state management with Pinia, efficient data fetching with composables, and TypeScript integration for type safety.

subpages.title: Project Structure and Organization
subpages.content:
Recommended Directory Structure

A well-organized Nuxt 3 project follows this structure:

├── components/
│   ├── base/        # Base UI components
│   ├── shared/      # Shared components
│   └── feature/     # Feature-specific components
├── composables/     # Auto-imported composables
├── layouts/         # Application layouts
├── pages/           # File-based routing
├── plugins/         # Nuxt plugins
├── server/          # Server routes and middleware
├── stores/          # Pinia stores
└── types/           # TypeScript type definitions

Auto-Import Best Practices

  • Place reusable composables in the composables/ directory for auto-import
  • Use the components/ directory with nested folders for automatic component registration
  • Prefix utility composables with use (e.g., useAuth, useFetch)

subpages.title: State Management with Pinia
subpages.content:
Why Pinia for Nuxt 3?

Pinia is the official state management solution for Vue 3 and Nuxt 3, offering:

  • Full TypeScript support with type inference
  • Devtools integration for debugging
  • SSR support out of the box
  • Modular design with composable stores

Store Best Practices

// stores/user.ts
export const useUserStore = defineStore('user', () => {
  const user = ref(null)
  const isAuthenticated = computed(() => !!user.value)
  
  async function login(credentials: LoginCredentials) {
    user.value = await $fetch('/api/auth/login', {
      method: 'POST',
      body: credentials
    })
  }
  
  return { user, isAuthenticated, login }
})

SSR Considerations

Always use useState() or Pinia stores for state that needs to be shared between server and client to avoid hydration mismatches.

subpages.title: Data Fetching Patterns
subpages.content:
Nuxt 3 Data Fetching Composables

Nuxt 3 provides powerful composables for data fetching:

  • useFetch: Full-featured data fetching with caching and SSR support
  • useAsyncData: For custom async operations
  • $fetch: Direct fetch utility based on ofetch
  • useLazyFetch: Non-blocking data fetching

Best Practices

// Use unique keys for caching
const { data, refresh } = await useFetch('/api/users', {
  key: 'users-list',
  transform: (response) => response.data,
  watch: [page, limit]
})

// Client-side only fetching
const { data } = await useFetch('/api/stats', {
  server: false
})

Error Handling

Always handle errors gracefully using the error return value and implement proper loading states with pending.

subpages.title: Performance Optimization
subpages.content:
Key Performance Strategies

1. Component Lazy Loading

Use defineAsyncComponent or the Lazy prefix for components that aren't needed immediately:

<LazyModalDialog v-if="showModal" />

2. Image Optimization

Use the Nuxt Image module for automatic image optimization:

<NuxtImg src="/hero.jpg" format="webp" quality="80" />

3. Bundle Analysis

Run nuxi analyze to identify large dependencies and optimize your bundle size.

4. Caching Strategies

  • Use routeRules for ISR (Incremental Static Regeneration)
  • Implement proper cache headers for API routes
  • Use useFetch caching with appropriate keys
